title: Semantic Technology: Applications in Industry
segmentation: OK, welcome back.

After the lunch break everybody and as we were saying this morning this afternoon session will last approximately 2 hours and I will focus on the applications in industry that we see for some of the semantic technologies that we were hearing about this morning and as part of that I'll ask Barry Norton to give a short resume on linked open data to just expand a bit on what he said this morning just to set the scene.
So one of the applications that I'm going to discuss.
So.

I'll start with a brief introduction to semantic technology that will very much reinforce what Barry was saying this morning about RDF and so forth, and I will then look at three kinds of application of semantic technology that we're looking at in BT in an industrial setting.
First of all, I look at knowledge management and the active project in particular.
Then I'll look at linked open data and an application we're developing there.
Finally, I'll look at business intelligence and how we're using semantic technology to build.
Better systems for business intelligence.

If this time, I'll also look at quite a specialized specific application in the health sector, which is using the owl Description logic language, which which Barry also mentioned earlier, and I'll finish with a brief look at the extent to which semantic technology is now being taken up in industry, and some resource is which you may find useful if you're interested in exploring semantic technology.
Selves.
So if we think about today's web, today's web is primarily aimed at a machine to human kind of paradigm.
So the machine represents the information and presents it to the human.
The human has to do the interpreting and linking of that information.
So today's web is primarily, I would argue, about presenting information in various ways, whether it's text, images, video, or whatever it may be.
And as Barry was saying, the semantic Web vision is very much.
A vision to extend the current web in order to give the information on the web better defined meaning so that that that information that's on the web is more amenable to machine processing.
So we can start to automate some of the processes that we have to do is humans today.
A simple example of a fragment of semantic web technology would be in HTML.
The language of today's web.
You can specify how how a character string is laid out on a web page.
So use bold font by by using these particular commands.
What we can do in XML then is not only specify how that should be laid out, but also specify what it means to specify that this particular string represents a product code, for example.
XML is a relatively simple approach and then again as Barry was saying, we want to go beyond XML into languages like RDF and OWL.
Formal ontological languages which support triples to model relationships between different pieces of data.
So.
XML is a first step.
HTML is all about layout.
XML is all about describing content.
And here's an example of an XML document.
This happens to be a Shakespeare play.
You can see that it's a play from the first tag there, which is play, and then we have the title of the play.
A list of the actors in the play Scene, One Act, one and so forth.
So simple fragment of XML telling you what the data, the actual text of the play is all.
About what we want to do is go a little bit beyond XML.
XML has some limitations.
It tends to work across within documents, but not across documents.
And Furthermore, there's no modeling of relationships between data items.
So if we look at this fragment here, we can see that this is a fragment of XML describing a vehicle.
The vehicles are car.
The car has an engine of a certain type, and the car is a certain model.
But what we don't understand, of course, is that the engine is part of the car, or that the model is a.
Type of car so we cannot model the relationships between these different data items and that essentially is what RDF allows you to do.
RDF Center Resource description framework.
It's a standard of the W 3C, and as Barry said it's all about triples subject property verb triples.
So we can say Tolkein wrote the book the Lord of the Rings.
We can write lots of these triples and then our DFS or RDF schema extends RDF with an ontology vocabulary, so we can say we can define classes and properties that we want to represent using our RDF.
So our DFS defines the ontology.
What I mean by that is the concepts that we want to represent and reason about in our particular domain of application and how they are related to one another.
So we might be interested in their authors.
Authors write books, books have product codes and product prices and so on and so forth.
So in the terminology of the semantic Web, what we would define his classes, the concepts and the properties and relationships between the classes.
So that's our DFS for defining the ontology.
And then RDF is used to define the instances that particular particularity's of these classes and their properties.
So Mark Twain is a kind of author Mark Twain wrote a book called The Adventures of Tom Sawyer, Adventures of Tom Sawyer is a book, and so on.
So RDF's for the ontology, the concept layer and then RDF to define the actual instances of these classes and properties that we've.
Find.

So here's an example that based on the one I was just looking at, we've defined a couple of classes, once called writer, once called book and there's a There's a relationship or a property holding between those two classes, which says that a writer has written a book and writer is called the domain of that property, and book is called the range, so the subject type is called a domain, and the property type.
Sorry, the object type is called the range.
We can also define subclasses of other classes.
So here, famous writer.
It's a subclass of writer, and that means that everything that that famous writer will inherit all the properties of writer.
It's a specialization of the class writer, so this is our DFS defining the domain ontology and then underneath the dotted line.
Here we have the actual data represented in RDF.
We have a urri representing Mark Twain who is a type of famous writer.
We would have a UI representing the has written property and you are I.
Representing the particular book which we want to say that Mark Twain wrote so very much along the same lines as Barry was talking about this morning, building up databases out of these triples.
So a word about ontologies and taxonomies.

Taxonomies are in very in a wire simplification of of an ontology where each node in the class hierarchy only has one parent and the single relationship between the concepts of the classes is a kind of so this should say animal here.
So an animal is a kind of living being, and vertebrates and invertebrates are both types of annual and similarly plants are also types of living being.
So that's an ontology.
Sorry, that's a taxonomy, which is a kind of subset.
If you like of and on.
Apology when we come on to ontologies.
We want to model a richer set of relationships between the classes.

As I was just saying so the example we have here is all about employees and contractors working for a company and you can see for a start you can see that some of the some of the classes have more than one superclass, more than one class above them.
And we might also want to have some properties or relationships between those classes.
So we might want to say that program managers fund project managers.
Experts advise project managers and so on.
So Ontology is a richer representation.
Taxonomy and the semantic web.

You know, a key building block of the semantic web is is ontologies because they give you a shared and common understanding of a particular domain and because they represented in formal ontological languages, they're much more amenable to machine processing, so it helps programs to gather, analyze, and search for information of certain types, because that information is defined against the particular on.
Balaji so while developing ontology, well as I've said to divine information more precisely more formally and therefore make it more amenable to machine processing.

But ontologies also make your domain assumptions explicit, so you understand exactly what you're assuming about a given domain, and if you think about a database type application, alot of those assumptions might be built up, built into your database schema and not so easily explicitly available and.
Easy to change.
We can also use an ontology to separate that domain representation from operational knowledge, so there can be a separation between the representation of the domain and the actual functions.
The operations that you perform on the knowledge in the domain.

Finally, ontologies allow a shared understanding of what information means because they're shared in their open, and because they're based on logical languages, they allow reasoning over data and inferences, and Barry gave us some examples this morning of how we can make inferences from sets of RDF triples.
We can infer newin.
Formation Nunu triples, and here's just a couple of examples we could have.
We could have rules too.

We could have rules to infer new information, so we could say if X Co wrote a document and why Co wrote a document, we could infer that XY collaborate, for example, just one simple example of the use of a ruler to infer and you triple from a previous trip.
So that's a very brief introduction to semantic technology that I just wanted to try and kind of reinforce some of the key messages that Barry was went into in a little bit more detail this morning.

Now I'd like to come on to the bulk of the talk, which is really about the application of semantic technology, and as I said, I'll start by looking at the active project and semantic technology for knowledge management.
So colleague of mine was asked to define semantic technology in three words and he came up with about 20 words.
As you can see here.
Semantic knowledge management classifieds finds distribute shares and uses knowledge based on meaning, not the particular words used to represent meaning and to his.
Credit he did manage to boil that down to three words.
The three words he came up with work meaning not words.
So if we've got a lot of knowledge represented in a natural language like English, French or whatever, it may be thing to point was made over here earlier.

Actually, that the similar meanings can be represented using different words, and what we'd like to use semantic technology to do is to get underneath that so that, for example, if I've got a document that mentions Netherlands and another one that mentions Holland, those words are synonymous for the same country.
Yeah, if I search on the word Holland, I'd like documents that mention the word Netherlands to still be returned, even though I haven't used exactly the right word in my query.
So semantic knowledge management is trying to get behind the words and actually reason and represent knowledge based on the meaning of the word.
So again, this came up this morning and Marco discuss this briefly.
You can have the same word with different meanings of Jaguar.
Could be a Wildcat or it could be a car.

You could have different words with the same meaning, disability legislation and equal opportunity laws in the UK at least mean very similar things and you can have different words with related meanings.
So company charity and organisations are all types and trade unions.
I'm sorry are all types of organisations, so in some sense those words.
Are related and you might want to inherit properties from organization to company or charity and others.
You might want to assume that whatever is true about an organization is also true about a company because the company is a special sort of organization.
So how do we so having made those observations about wanting to get the meaning of the words rather than the words themselves, how do we actually do that?
Well, we build.

We can create a domain ontology as we were talking about earlier, and then given a piece of text, we can then perform, we called semantic annotation over that text and this involves using text analytic technology such as named entity recognition to identify particular character strings in the text particular words, phrases.
And associate them with particular instances in the ontology.
And the interesting thing to note here is that BT of course represents is annotated with the instance BT, but also this pronoun here.
It's has also been the linguistic processing of the text analytics technology.
Identify that this pronoun it's is also referring to BT so you can see that we're getting away from the particular character strings used to represent a particular entity there.
An which whichever character strings represent the entity.
We can still understand that that character string refers to BT.
So how might this help us?

Well, here's an example of what we call semantic browsing using a tool called Kim, which in fact we're using it in BT and we'll see later another system that we built that uses Kim and what Kim can do is analyze this text.
We've got a web browser here and on this site we got a standard sort of web page.
This one happens to be from the BBC website, but what Kim does is analyze the text and he actually color codes different strings within the text.
Against a particular ontology.
So countries like UK and South Korea here are color coded in a particular color.
Microsoft, which represents a company, is color coded in another color.

US again is color coded so you can start to start to understand which entities particular pieces of particular pieces of text actually refer to, and if we've got an ontology behind this, like the ontology that we see represented on the left there.
We can actually go.

Step further and given a particular entity like Microsoft, we can extract the information that we hold in our domain ontology in our knowledge base if you like and represent it in a sort of natural language style like this.

So this is a fragment of text all about Microsoft which has been extracted from the more formal generated from the more formal representation in description logic that we hold about Microsoft in our particular ontology.
This, this one comes from ontology that happens to be called proton.
That was developed by the same guys who developed Kim, a small company called on to text from Bulgaria.
So you can see that by browsing around and associating information with an ontology, you can get some quite useful supplementary information as you browse the information in which.

You're interested in, so that's browsing, but similarly, in semantic search we can also use the same kind of structures to perform search, which isn't based on purely on keywords like the example I gave earlier, like Holland and Netherlands and those synonyms.
But it is based on the meaning behind the words, so semantic search could match.
A query.
Might be I want to find out about documents concerning a telecoms company in Europe with the new director.
With.

A document containing this string here at its meeting on the 10th of May, the board of the UK company Vodafone, appointed John Smith as chairman and you can see that I think the only word meaning substantiative word that occurs in both the query and the document is the word company and yet this document is clearly very relevant to this particular query, even though very few of the words intersect.
Ontology based search can do the required reasoning to understand how.
How similar, how closely related that query is with that particular document?
Because if you represent the information in an ontology, you could for example understand that Vodafone is a mobile operator, which in turn is a kind of telecom company.
Similarly, Vodafone is in the UK, which is a part of Europe, and similarly again a chairman is a type of director.
So you can see that we can make links between the query and the document Chairman, Director, UK, Europe.

Vodafone telecoms even though that the actual words used within the query and the document are in fact quite different so we can get much more precise matches than is possible with the standard keyword keyword search.
Approach.
So that's a brief look at semantic technology and knowledge management.

It's an EU integrating project with twelve partners.
I was seven countries.
I won't go through.
Through this again.

I was saying how there are two key technology themes, context management helping users switch between context when they get interrupted, and doing that as efficiently as possible so they don't lose the thread of their thought or they can quickly get the information to hand for the new context and knowledge sharing with semantic technology.
If I'm doing something within an organization, suppose I'm putting together a bid for a particular customer.
How can I find out which other proposals which other bids have been made to other customers?
On the same topic area to make sure that I don't reinvent the wheel, I don't waste my time creating a proposal when somebody else in the company has already done something very similar.
So those are the two key themes.
Of the project.
Little bit more about context management contest scene.
As I was saying before, any key to the two affective information delivery and what is a context will vary depending on the kind of role that you have in the kind of user that you are.
So for a sales person, they've got four different customers that they deal with day-to-day basis.
Each customer might, for them, represent a different context.
Similarly, with a lawyer, it might be the different cases that they're dealing with at any particular time.
And so on and so forth.
But the key point in active is that we're not all prescriptive about this.

A user can choose what context is right according to their particular job, their particular role, and the use of context is used to guide the presentation of emails, files, search results, and so forth.
So all the information that is presented to the user is effectively filtered through this context to make it as relevant to the users current work as possible.
And there are two ways in which contexts of setup and and managed.
One is a very top down approach.
The user can specify.
I've got 3 customers, customer 1, two and three.
Those are going to be my context and I'm going to associate these kinds of information with the three different contexts.

But we're also employing some of the machine learning knowledge discovery techniques that Marco was talking about this morning to kind of automatically observe what the user is doing, and perhaps discover new contexts.

So we might, for example, notice that there's a new cluster of information that's not currently associated with any particular context, and that might then suggest to us that the user has now is now working in a new context that he hasn't specified before, and the machine learning technology can then suggest to the user.

You might be working in some new context.
Here's the information which seems to be relevant to this context.

Would you like to create a new context so the software will start to automatically suggest to use a new context, which they may like to define to help them in their work and enable them to access information more efficiently?
OK, so that was a bit about context.
I want to switch now to thinking about knowledge sharing with a tool called the Semantic Mediawiki.
Classic media wiki.
You're probably familiar with wikis which are very useful collaborative tools where multiple people can edit the same documents in a web based environment.

Right in the pure text you can.
You can specify that London is linked to the UK by.
This relationship is capital of and this is then stored within the wiki in a more formal way.

OK, so the customer that we're using in beta test, this active technology is BT business.
BT Business is a sales Department of BT selling mainly to small and medium enterprises in the UK right?

Ranging from a small business employing three people maybe on a single site right up to some very large multi outlet retail chains that go right across the whole country and we're trialing active technology with the BT business Salesforce.
In particular, account managers, sales specialists, technical solutions, consultants, and these.

These users typically work with multiple customers at the same time, and what's more, given a particular customer and account manager who's looking after that customer will bring together different people on our sort of virtual team basis so the team will form to perhaps create a proposal for a particular customer involving particular specialists and consultants, and then disband again very quickly.
So it's quite a dynamic.
Environment where people are working together in virtual teams which come together and disband and also where people are working with multiple customers at the same time.
Time.
So we looked at these this this user group and we performed a requirements capture exercise and we we came up with some key requirements.
One was easier context switching so as I said they might have many customers and many many products and services.
And they would like to be able to when they switch to a new customer, have the information precisely about that customer very easily to hand.
So that was one key aspect of getting the right information according to the particular customer there dealing with the second key aspect was this issue of the solution design.
How can they more quickly design a solution for a particular customer, perhaps using multiple products and services?
And because of the reason for wanting to do that quickly, is that analysis revealed that the speed of response to the customer very much influenced the win rate.

The chances of actually winning that that bid and getting that business from the customer and the other thing that they wanted to do around this whole area of solution design was to see how they might be able to reuse previous bids, previous customer proposals.
'cause as I said before, typically what's happening at the moment is.

People are creating a new bid for a new customer from scratch and then they find out later that there was already a very similar bid had been previously created by it by another guy, so I'd really like to reuse that knowledge and avoid the waste of duplicated effort.

So there are two sides then, to the trials in BT that we've done with these BT business users, we created a semantic wiki for solution design and we created an active knowledge workspace for personal productivity and context management.
So this one is all about sharing solution designs using a semantic wiki.
This one much more about context management and the delivery of context specific information.

Knowledge.

So if you work in a team and you want to have a shared context where information is shared between you that is also supported by the system.
In one aspect of a KWS is what we call a context visualizer, and that's what we can see on the screenshot here.
So we've got a context.

In this case, it's called active, and we visualized the set of users so sheated with the active context, a set of tasks that those users typically carry out on the active context, and a set of information is a bunch of word documents here and some presentations and spreadsheets and so forth here.
So you can very quickly visualize.
The whole set of information associated with the context and click on whichever piece of information you need to access at the particular time.
There are various otherwise where context comes into play.
You probably familiar if you open a file in Word for Windows, you get a long list of historical previous files.
You've most recently opened.

Inactive you can also open a file from context and this will only list for you the most recently open files in the context in which you're in, so that long list is automatically filtered down to show you the most relevant previously open files to your current context.

Similarly, in email, each email can be associated with the context and context is in added as an additional field to your Outlook inbox, and you can search by context by clicking on this field or you know and then you'll get a list of emails in a particular context in which you are interested.

Re ranking emails according to your interests.

Your context is not only about emails, it's about emails.
It's about word documents about PowerPoint documents about other people and context can be shared between groups of users, OK?
So we're trialing the KWS with a restricted, yet set of users at the moment, around 10 to 15 at the start, which was at the start of January over January, February.
The project actually ends at the end of February.

We're ramping up to somewhere between 100 and 150 users, and as part of this current process that we're going through, we have a formal trial evaluation procedure in place with one of our active partners and the results of that trial evaluation should be due.
Shortly after the end of the project in March, so coming up very very soon now.
So pulling it together then with that.
It if it's about using informal semantics, lightweight semantics as exemplified in the Semantic Mediawiki, and it's about using machine intelligence.
The GSI technology to combat information overload on the one hand, and to aid information sharing.
On the other hand, it's being trialled in quite large scale enterprise environments.
And actually there is a prototype a KWS system which you can download from the active website, and we've got some active leaflets here.
If you want to pick one up, it's got the website on it, and it's got some more information about the active projects will be apart of these here at the front at the end of the day.
